results.title: Beyond sorrow beyond pain
results.brief_description: An emotionally moving re-enactment of the rehabilitation of a car accident victim who is blind and severely brain damaged. His girl friend is determined he should be rehabilitated with dignity and devotes years of her life to this end. Finally she is exhausted and must reconsider her position.

results.title: Beyond silence
results.creator_credit: United States Information Service, Milner-Fenwick and Edmond Levy
results.brief_description: The story of Gallaudet College in Washington D.C., where the deaf are trained to prepare themselves for the hearing world. Follows a new student from class to class and shows how the deaf are simultaneously taught lip-reading and sign language in the course of enrollment in a regular four year college curriculum leading to a Bachelor of Arts or Bachelor of Science degree. Explains that hearing students from other countries receive instruction at the Gallaudet Graduate School in the art of teaching the deaf.

results.title: Beyond reasonable doubt: the Ronald Ryan case
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Murray Travis and Stephen Ramsey
results.brief_description: A dramatised recreation of the trial of Ronald Ryan for the murder of a Pentridge prison officer with events leading up to the trial and a re-examination of the evidence. Ronald Ryan was the last man hanged in Australia in 1967. He was sentenced to death for allegedly shooting a warder while escaping from Pentridge Prison in the company of fellow prisoner, Peter Walker. Presenter Gordon Hawkins re-examines the scenario put forward by the prosecution at Ryan’s trial, using animated re-enactments and discussion of forensic evidence offered at the trial. He investigates the possibility that Ryan’s conviction was made without him being given the benefit of the doubt, and discusses the inequities and problems the trial system itself can create for the accused person at trial. Starring Bill Hunter as Ronald Ryan.

results.title: Beyond reasonable doubt: the Leith Rattan case
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Murray Travis and Tristram Miall
results.brief_description: Leith Rattan was found guilty of murdering his wife Beverly in their Echuca home and sentenced to death by hanging in a Shepparton Court. However, the verdict took many people by surprise and the sentence was later commuted to 25 years in prison. Rattan had always staunchly maintained that the shooting was an accident, although the police investigation seemingly identified a motive and opportunity. There were four appeals to higher courts on the grounds of the prosecution’s evidence and the original judgment made, however they were all dismissed. Through dramatised re-enactment and a thorough explanation of the forensic evidence offered at the original trial, presenter Gordon Hawkins casts doubt over the veracity of the evidence presented by the prosecution and asks was Rattan’s guilt proven beyond reasonable doubt? He also makes the point that the trial process itself is fraught with inequities and can often affect the accused person’s chance of a fair trial.

results.title: Beyond reason
results.creator_credit: Allwyn Pictures Corp, Arthur M Sarkissian, Howard W. Koch and Telly Savalas
results.brief_description: Well-known TV actor Telly Savalas stars in “Beyond Reason”, the only film he wrote and directed. “Beyond Reason” is an intriguing exploration into the relationship between doctor and patient and the degree of humanity that is normally allowed in this relation. Savalas plays Dr. Nicholas Mati, a psychiatrist in a mental hospital with a very unconventional approach to his patients. In fact, the film opens with a high-energy sequence in which a group of men are gambling with dice; it only becomes clear later that this group comprises a doctor and his patients. This underscores Mati’s ‘eccentric’ approach toward psychic recuperation, he favours love, warmth and compassion over clinical distance; an approach, however, which gets him into conflict with his superior, makes some of his colleagues uncomfortable and even confuses his students during lectures. Above all, Mati is shown to treat his patients as ‘humans’, and with exactly the same warmth and affection with which he relates to his family and friends in the ‘normal’ world. However, a gnawing sense of anxiety and paranoia leads the doctor to a crisis of confidence, triggered when one of his students questions his particular philosophy. A series of delusions and imaginings in which his approach is questioned and mocked culminates in hallucinatory madness, and it’s not until then that the doctor breaks through his crisis and re-gains a position of normality and confidence. “Beyond Reason” affirms its pro-humanity stance when it suggests how easily we can all slip into madness and how important understanding and sensitivity are at such times. Cast also includes Diana Muldaur, Laura Johnson and Marvin Laird.

results.title: Beyond Rangoon
results.creator_credit: Castle Rock Entertainment, John Boorman, Barry Spikings and Eric Plestow
results.brief_description: Patricia Arquette stars as American doctor Laura Bowman who flees to Burma on a package tour with her sister, Andy (Frances McDormand), following a family tragedy. Rather than achieve the peace and solitude she is desperately searching for, she encounters problems when the clash between peaceful protest and a militant government take an ugly turn. Andy flees the country, but Laura finds herself alone after being separated from her tour group, and without an identity after her passport is stolen at a political rally. She is befriended by a former professor (Aung Ko) who attempts to help her reach the Thailand border, and an allegory is drawn between a young woman’s plight to reach freedom and that of a nation facing political unrest. On their journey they witness firsthand the political struggle encountered by a group of dissidents. Cast also includes Spalding Gray and Victor Slezak.

results.title: Beyond our vision
results.creator_credit: Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute and David Hopwood
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Developing image”.
The need for accurate recording through photographs is examined, in both the past and the present. The program explores Western survey photography, including an original Western survey album used to persuade Congress to make Yellowstone National Park, Eadweard Muybridge’s stop-action photography and Landsat satellite imagery. Photography can now provide viewers insight into places, objects and events, beyond their personal experience.

results.title: Beyond LSD: a film for concerned adults and teenagers
results.creator_credit: Film Associates, Paul Burnford Film Productions and Paul Burnford
results.brief_description: This 1960’s film is about the communication gap between two generations: teenagers and young adults on the one hand, and the generation of those over thirty - “the establishment”. The teenagers’ use of LSD and other drugs is only one of the symptoms of this communication gap. A group of parents desperately seek help in order to understand what has gone wrong. The film is an attempt to go “beyond LSD” and is intended to stimulate discussion amongst high school students, college students, teachers and parents. Ample involuntary hilarity can result from viewing this great hysterical/historical document. Starting as a raucous celluloid freak-out, the film presents its square’s-eye view of the “Generation Gap” through the fictive device of a round table of pod people, each alike in their helmet-hair and cat’s eye glasses. The production crew of this film was primarily made up of teenagers and young adults. Music by ‘The Stayns.’ A minor masterpiece of psychedelic cinema.

results.title: Beyond kicks
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Michael McKennirey, George Pearson and Gary Toole
results.brief_description: This is about a group of young volunteers, the Free Youth Clinic, who run a ‘crisis bus’ to rescue young people experiencing bad drug trips, usually LSD. They pull up whenever the need arises and try to talk the person down. If the patient needs further medical aid, they know where to obtain it. The film shows some of the patients being interviewed after their rescue.

results.title: Beyond hell's gate
results.creator_credit: Satonyx Films, Nomad Films, Film Australia, Peter Johnson and David Roberts
results.brief_description: Three trailbike riders retrace the route that led 15,000 Chinese and 1,500 Europeans from Cooktown through Hell’s Gate to the Palmer Goldfields of Northern Queensland. Partly dramatised, it recounts the coming of the chinese, conflicts with the Aborigines and shows remnants of Maytown, the old mining settlement of Christie Palmerston, a legendary figure of the period.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Satonyx Films, Nomad Films, Film Australia, Peter Johnson and David Roberts
